the Prism exhibited a great variety of them, ranged irregula [rly?]
up & downe in the forme of waves. And so Bubbles of 
Water, before they began to Exhibit their colours to the nak[ed]
eye of a by Stander, haue appeared, through a Prisme, girded 
about with many paralell & horizontall Rings; to produce 
wch effect, it was necessary to hold the Prism paralell or 
very nearly paralell to the Horizon, & to dispose it so that 
the Rayes might be refracted upwards.
Haueing given my Observac[i]ons of these colours 
before I make use of them to unfold the Causes of the 
colours of naturall bodyes, it is convenient that by the 
Simplest of them I first explaine the more compounded,
Such as are the 2d 3d.4th.9th.12th.13th:20th: & 24ty.
And first to show how the colours in the 4 & 12th 
Observac[i]ons are produced, let there be taken in any right 
line the Lengths yZ, yA, &
yH in proportion as 4, 9 & 14 &
between ZA & ZH ele<s>a<\s>uen 
mean proporc[i]onalls, of which 
let ZB be the second, ZC the 
third, ZD the fift, ZE the seaventh,
ZF the Ninth, & ZG the Tenth.
And at the points A,B,C,D,E,F,
G,H, let p[er]pendiculars A[alpha], B[beta], &c
be erected by whose Intervalls, the 
Extent of the Seu[er]all colours set 
underneath ag[ain]st them, is to be represented.
Then divide the Line A[alpha] in such 
proporc[i]on as the Numbers 1, 2, 3;
5.6.7.9.10.11; &c. <s>Let<\s> set at the point 
of Division, denote. And through 
those Divisions from Y draw 
lines 1I, 2k, 3L; 5M, 6N, 7O; &c
Now if A2 be supposed to 
represent the thicknes of any thin 
transparent body at wch the utmost 
violet is most copiously reflected in 
the first Ring or series of colours,
then, by the 13th Observac[i]on, HK will represent its thickness at wch 
the utmost Red is most copiously reflected in the same series.
Also by the 5t. & 16. observac[i]ons A6. & HN will denote the 
thicknesses at wch those extream colours are most copiously reflected
